title: Buccaneers coach Bruce Arians: NFL 'referees aren't held accountable' for mistakes
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: Believe it or not we have all but reached the halfway point of the NFL regular season. As Lorenzo Reyes details, the league's elite class is starting to crystalize. USA TODAY

One day later, Bruce Arians is still annoyed.

The head coach of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers again addressed an apparent officiating mistake that may have cost the team the game in a 27-23 loss Sunday to the Tennessee Titans.

“Not to beat a dead horse, but an inadvertent whistle, if we had in the last three minutes and some change, a three-point lead and win the game, I think everybody is writing different stories, talking different things,” Arians said. “So it was more than just a play. Everybody except for one guy saw the ball out. Blew a quick whistle.

"My biggest thing is, referees aren't held accountable. Coaches get fired. General managers get fired. Players get cut. Referees aren't accountable. And it's a shame. It's been that way for 40 years and now that we've got a new agreement, it'll be that way for 40 more years.”

With 3:45 left to play in the game, the Titans ran a fake field goal in which punter Brett Kern was stopped short of the line of scrimmage. An official blew the whistle quickly, effectively ending the play and calling the runner down by contact.

Television replays, however, showed that Buccaneers linebacker Devin White had jarred the ball loose before Kern hit the ground. Tampa safety Andrew Adams scooped the ball and had a clear path to the end zone in what almost certainly would have been a touchdown. But because the play was blown dead, the return was not reviewable.

Though the Buccaneers got the ball back, they couldn’t score a touchdown and eventually lost the game.

Despite Arians' comments, the NFL does go through a process of grading officials, and determines their potential assignment to high-profile games like the Super Bowl based on their track record.

Blowing plays dead, however, has been an issue for NFL officials this season. The New Orleans Saints also had an apparent touchdown wiped away because of an early whistle in Week 2, when defensive end Cameron Jordan had a clear 87-yard fumble return for a touchdown against the Los Angeles Rams negated.

New Orleans went on to lose that game, 27-9.

Though a different circumstance, in last week’s Houston Texans-Indianapolis Colts game, quarterback Deshaun Watson tried to extend a play and also had a score wiped off the board because of a quick whistle. On that play, Colts defensive end Justin Houston had Watson’s ankles as he tried to bring him down, but Watson fired a quick pass to receiver DeAndre Hopkins for what would’ve been a 4-yard touchdown.

Instead, an official blew the play dead and counted it as a sack. The Texans then had to settle for a field goal. Houston lost, 30-23.

“Again, it was an inadvertent whistle,” Arians continued. “So, yeah, why has it continued? Since the Rams-Saints game the second week, when the Saints got the touchdown that they didn’t get, there’s been an emphasis on letting the plays go. If you can answer why it’s not happening – I don’t know.”

In a pool report after the Titans-Bucs game, referee Adrian Hill confirmed that replay review would only have been able to give the Buccaneers the ball based on a disputed fumble, but that Tampa wouldn’t have been able to advance it any further.

“Certainly after the whistle, we definitely saw a ball come out afterwards, but the ruling on the field was that the runner was down by contact before the ball came out, and that's why the whistle blew,” Hill said. “So the whistle was blown because the ruling was ‘runner down by contact.’”

description: After a quick whistle may have cost the Buccaneers a loss on Sunday, coach Bruce Arians lamented the state of officiating in the NFL.
